transcript.text: It’s important to consider how a situation might look to an outsider. Could it look like you were influenced by preferential treatment or favoritism? If so, it might be a conflict. Here are some situations where conflicts can come up.

contentText.text: Here are some common situations that create conflicts of interest:

instructionText.text: Select each heading. To read the next, click the X to close the text box.
Click on Next (bottom right arrow) to continue.

revealCallOut.buttonText: A friend or family member works – or wants to work – for Johnson Controls.

popText.text: If a friend or relative works or applies for work at Johnson Controls, that’s not automatically a conflict of interest.

However, if you have the authority to make or influence decisions that could affect their position – like hiring, raises, bonuses, job promotions, etc. – then this does create a conflict and must be disclosed.

revealCallOut.img: Family member working with Johnson controls supplier
revealCallOut.buttonText: A friend or family member works for one of Johnson Controls’ vendors, suppliers, clients or competitors.

popText.text: This situation is a potential conflict of interest and must be disclosed.
It’s likely you will also have to stay removed from any business decisions that concern Johnson Controls and the company for whom your friend or relative works.

revealCallOut.img: Stock Traders making a family member’s trade
revealCallOut.buttonText: You have, or a member of your immediate family has a large financial stake in a client, supplier or competitor.

popText.text: Investing in an outside company is not generally a conflict of interest, unless you have a significant interest in one of Johnson Controls’ clients, suppliers or competitors. When your personal financial gains (or those of a member of your immediate family) are affected by Johnson Controls’ decisions and actions, this creates a potential conflict of interest that needs to be disclosed.

revealCallOut.img: Employee talking with manager about potential job conflict
revealCallOut.buttonText: You work for another company outside of Johnson Controls.

popText.text:
Outside employment by itself is not prohibited, but it can become a conflict of interest in certain instances, for example if:
  • Your responsibilities outside of Johnson Controls affect your job responsibilities or performance at Johnson Controls.
  • Your outside position requires the use of Johnson Controls property, information or connections.
  • You hold a position with a vendor, supplier, client or customer of Johnson Controls.
  • You support a Johnson Controls competitor directly or indirectly.
In these situations, you must report your employment – or potential employment – to Johnson Controls in order to obtain permission to continue.
